item.title: Attraction draft
item.description: Graph 1 This graph is showing how people feel about scientists getting acurate information about the world now. I've used the orange (represents 100%) to temporarily to highlight the trend. Smaller circles on the left than the right. Graph 2 This graph is showing how people feel about science impact of jobs in 5 years. I've used the orange (represents 100%) to temporarily to highlight the trend.

item.title: Benefits
item.description: Benefits 1 in 5 people feel personally excluded from the benefits of science. How far removed might people feel they are from the benefits of science? Globally, distrust in science is moderately correlated (0.65 correlation) with saying science does not benefit the country. LMICs are 1.3 times less likely to say that science benefits most people in their country as compared to upper middle and high income countries.

item.title: Future Economies
item.description: Future Economies As economies evolve, they may become more likely to trust that scientists provide accurate information and more skeptical of science’s ability to increase jobs. How likely are people to think that science can help create a better future? Understanding the desirability of a world shaped by science and technology for India and Bangladesh.-- As economies undergo a transition from production of goods to provision of services they start to relate more to the benefits of science and trusting scientists to provide accurate information — while becoming more skeptical about science’s ability to increase jobs.

item.title: Orientation draft
item.description: THE LENS OF RELIGION Coexistence of religion and science Four instances of when religion impacted health behaviours, negatively & positively According to WGM 2018, People who live in LMIC countries are more likely to identify as religious as compared to the rest of the world. 64% of them report an uncomplicated side-by-side relationship of faith in religion and science. When the two schools of thought disagree - 13% of them create a hierarchy, elevating religion over science.

item.title: Religion
item.description: Religion Globally, 20% of respondents see a conflict between religious and scientific teachings and 11% of the population would choose religion over science. Where might people turn when there is a difference of opinion between religion and science? According to WGM 2018, people who live in LMICs are more likely to identify as religious as compared to the rest of the world. 66% of them report an uncomplicated side-by-side relationship of faith in religion and science.

item.title: Societal Institutions
item.description: Societal Institutions 29 countries out of 144 distrust scientists equally or more than other societal groups. How much or how little are different societal groups in a country trusted, and does this affect trust in scientists? Understanding the desirability of a world shaped by science and technology for India and Bangladesh.-- Globally, A general distrust of society correlates with distrust of scientists in a country.
